category_summary:
**OpenAI** dominated the day's discourse with **Sam Altman** announcing **GPT-5.3-Codex** [rolling out](/?date=2026-02-10&category=social#item-7d2439afa80f) to **Cursor**, **GitHub**, and **VS Code**, alongside the milestone of [1M+ **Codex App** downloads](/?date=2026-02-10&category=social#item-00ef1e57cd16) in its first week. Altman framed 5.3 as a stepping stone—'[not solved yet](/?date=2026-02-10&category=social#item-9a13d5cba8f6), but 5.3 will help build the thing that solves it'—while revealing [cybersecurity concerns are gating](/?date=2026-02-10&category=social#item-277be016615d) the API rollout.

- **OpenAI** began [testing **ads in ChatGPT**](/?date=2026-02-10&category=social#item-ad34943c6a96) for US free/Go users, marking a major monetization shift that drew intense community debate
- **OpenAI's Super Bowl LX ad** ('You can just build things') hit 2.3M views, signaling aggressive mainstream consumer positioning
- **Simon Willison** [highlighted **HBR research**](/?date=2026-02-10&category=social#item-a2937db66508) showing AI productivity boosts can cause burnout and mental exhaustion, resonating widely with practitioners
- **Perplexity** CEO **Arav Srinivas** announced [upgrading Deep Research](/?date=2026-02-10&category=social#item-05e205f83131) to **Claude Opus 4.6**, claiming benchmark leadership over **Google**
- **Nathan Lambert** [published detailed analysis](/?date=2026-02-10&category=social#item-d8e880aa037d) of **Opus 4.6** and **Codex 5.3**, calling Claude the agent king but noting benchmarks are increasingly inadequate for evaluation in 2026
- **Ethan Mollick** observed that [faking continual learning](/?date=2026-02-10&category=social#item-38dd778f6519) and memory for AIs works surprisingly well, predicting true continual learning would be a major breakthrough
category_summary_html:
OpenAI dominated the day's discourse with Sam Altman announcing GPT-5.3-Codex rolling out to Cursor, GitHub, and VS Code, alongside the milestone of 1M+ Codex App downloads in its first week. Altman framed 5.3 as a stepping stone—'not solved yet, but 5.3 will help build the thing that solves it'—while revealing cybersecurity concerns are gating the API rollout.

  • OpenAI began testing ads in ChatGPT for US free/Go users, marking a major monetization shift that drew intense community debate
  • OpenAI's Super Bowl LX ad ('You can just build things') hit 2.3M views, signaling aggressive mainstream consumer positioning
  • Simon Willison highlighted HBR research showing AI productivity boosts can cause burnout and mental exhaustion, resonating widely with practitioners
  • Perplexity CEO Arav Srinivas announced upgrading Deep Research to Claude Opus 4.6, claiming benchmark leadership over Google
  • Nathan Lambert published detailed analysis of Opus 4.6 and Codex 5.3, calling Claude the agent king but noting benchmarks are increasingly inadequate for evaluation in 2026
  • Ethan Mollick observed that faking continual learning and memory for AIs works surprisingly well, predicting true continual learning would be a major breakthrough

themes.name: OpenAI Codex & GPT-5.3 Launch
themes.description: GPT-5.3-Codex rolling out to major IDEs (Cursor, GitHub, VS Code), with 1M+ downloads in first week, 60%+ user growth, cybersecurity-related API delays, and Altman framing 5.3 as a stepping stone toward solving harder problems.

themes.name: ChatGPT Ads Introduction
themes.description: OpenAI begins testing ads in ChatGPT for free/Go US users, marking a significant monetization and business model shift with potential trust implications.

themes.name: AI Productivity Paradox and Burnout
themes.description: HBR research and personal accounts showing that AI-driven productivity gains can lead to mental exhaustion and burnout—a nuanced counterpoint to pure productivity narratives.

themes.name: Opus 4.6 Early Adoption
themes.description: Perplexity rapidly upgrading to Claude Opus 4.6 (released Feb 5) for their Deep Research product, claiming benchmark leadership. Signals fast commercial adoption of latest Anthropic models.

themes.name: Opus 4.6 vs Codex 5.3 Analysis
themes.description: Nathan Lambert's detailed comparative analysis of the two latest major model releases, declaring Claude still king but Codex closing the gap. Notes benchmarks are increasingly inadequate for evaluation.

themes.name: Claude Opus 4.6 Adoption
themes.description: Multiple signals showing Opus 4.6 rolling out broadly: Anthropic giving nonprofits access, Perplexity adopting it for Deep Research, and Swyx's glowing double-blind arena review calling it dominant over all peer models.

themes.name: Intelligence Theory & Deep Learning Limitations
themes.description: Chollet argues current AI (gradient descent) cannot autonomously produce composable, durable abstractions — a fundamental requirement for intelligence. Only math/code achieve this outside the human mind.

themes.name: OpenAI Super Bowl Codex Campaign
themes.description: OpenAI aired a Codex-focused ad during Super Bowl LX with the tagline 'You can just build things', achieving massive engagement (2.3M views). A landmark moment for AI coding tools reaching mainstream audiences.

themes.name: Claude Code / Model Degradation Concerns
themes.description: Multiple posts from levelsio and corroborating replies about perceived quality degradation in Claude Code after Opus 4.6 launch. Massive engagement (232K views on main post) suggesting widespread user frustration.

themes.name: LLM Capabilities and Limitations
themes.description: Observations about what LLMs can and cannot do well, particularly the surprising difficulty of medium-length creative fiction compared to more 'technical' tasks.

items.content:
More than 1 million people downloaded Codex App in the first week.

60+% growth in overall Codex user last week!

We'll keep Codex available to Free/Go users after this promotion; we may have to reduce limits there but we want everyone to be able to try Codex and start building.

items.title: We’re starting to roll out a test for ads in ChatGPT today to a subset of free and Go users in the U...
items.content:
We’re starting to roll out a test for ads in ChatGPT today to a subset of free and Go users in the U.S.

Ads do not influence ChatGPT’s answers. Ads are labeled as sponsored and visually separate from the response.

Our goal is to give everyone access to ChatGPT for free with fewer limits, while protecting the trust they place in it for important and personal tasks.

https://t.co/zwETrWOnTr

Ads are labeled as sponsored and visually separate from responses. States ads don't influence ChatGPT's answers.
items.reasoning: Major business model shift for OpenAI — introducing advertising into ChatGPT. Extremely high engagement (2.9K likes, 594K views, 308 quotes). Raises significant questions about trust, incentive alignment, and the future of AI monetization.

items.title: So much work is going into faking continual learning and memory for AIs, and it works better than ex...
items.content: So much work is going into faking continual learning and memory for AIs, and it works better than expected in practice, so much so that it makes me think that, if continual learning is actually achieved, the results are going to really shift the AI ability frontier very quickly.
items.author: @emollick
items.summary: Mollick observes that faking continual learning and memory for AIs works better than expected, and predicts that if true continual learning is achieved, it will rapidly shift the AI capability frontier.
items.reasoning: High-signal observation about an important technical frontier. Strong engagement (665 likes, 46K views). Continual learning is a key unsolved problem, and Mollick's insight about proxy approaches working well is notable.

items.title: A good solution to the intelligence problem should be able to autonomously produce abstractions that...
items.content: A good solution to the intelligence problem should be able to autonomously produce abstractions that compose well, stack well, and stand the test of time. Without cribbing them from somewhere else. So far there's no tech that achieves this. Gradient descent certainly doesn't.
items.author: @fchollet
items.summary: Chollet argues a true solution to intelligence must autonomously produce abstractions that compose well, stack well, and stand the test of time — and that no current technology, including gradient descent, achieves this.
items.reasoning: Core thesis from one of the most credible voices on AI intelligence benchmarking (ARC creator). Directly challenges current deep learning paradigm. Good engagement (200+ likes).
items.summary_html: Chollet argues a true solution to intelligence must autonomously produce abstractions that compose well, stack well, and stand the test of time — and that no current technology, including gradient descent, achieves this.
items.content_html: A good solution to the intelligence problem should be able to autonomously produce abstractions that compose well, stack well, and stand the test of time. Without cribbing them from somewhere else. So far there's no tech that achieves this. Gradient descent certainly doesn't.

items.title: So far “telling a satisfying and well-written medium-length story” has proved far harder for LLMs th...
items.content:
So far “telling a satisfying and well-written medium-length story” has proved far harder for LLMs than mathematical proofs, music generation, research reports, code, and many other forms of work.

The technical reasons are pretty clear, but they are supposed to be language models
items.author: @emollick
items.summary: Ethan Mollick observes that writing satisfying medium-length stories remains harder for LLMs than math proofs, music generation, research reports, and code — noting the irony since they're 'language models'.
items.reasoning: Insightful observation from a leading AI commentator about a persistent LLM limitation. Good engagement. Highlights an underappreciated gap in AI capabilities.

items.title: A corporate position that workers should "just use AI to do stuff" has never been enough. AI use in ...
items.content: A corporate position that workers should "just use AI to do stuff" has never been enough. AI use in companies is a leadership problem that involves answering fundamental questions about what people should do with their time, how work is organized, and how to center people in work
items.author: @emollick
items.summary: Mollick argues that telling workers to 'just use AI' is insufficient — AI adoption in companies is a leadership problem requiring fundamental rethinking of work organization, time allocation, and centering people.
items.reasoning: Substantive insight on enterprise AI adoption from a leading researcher on AI and work. Strong engagement (309 likes, 36K views). Highly relevant to current corporate AI strategies.

items.title: @windsurf ok i think after spending enough time with Opus 4.6 in double-blinded arena mode tests i f...
items.content:
@windsurf ok i think after spending enough time with Opus 4.6 in double-blinded arena mode tests i feel like i can articulate some qualities I strongly appreciate:

- it's very diligent where other models (incl K2.5) are lazy
- it has no hesitation writing throwaway test files 
- it presents results well as tables
- it is fantastic at performance profiling, try it
- for simple questions it terminates MUCH faster than peer frontier models
- it communicates chain of thought very well

basically this thing is just destroying every other model in our Frontier arena.
items.author: @swyx
items.summary: Swyx provides detailed review of Claude Opus 4.6 after double-blinded arena testing: praises diligence, speed for simple questions, performance profiling, chain-of-thought communication, and says it's dominating their Frontier arena.
items.reasoning: High-quality first-hand evaluation of Opus 4.6 from respected AI engineer/influencer. Specific, actionable observations. Strongly positive assessment that it's 'destroying every other model' in arena testing.
items.summary_html: Swyx provides detailed review of Claude Opus 4.6 after double-blinded arena testing: praises diligence, speed for simple questions, performance profiling, chain-of-thought communication, and says it's dominating their Frontier arena.
items.content_html:
@windsurf ok i think after spending enough time with Opus 4.6 in double-blinded arena mode tests i feel like i can articulate some qualities I strongly appreciate:

  • it's very diligent where other models (incl K2.5) are lazy
  • it has no hesitation writing throwaway test files
  • it presents results well as tables
  • it is fantastic at performance profiling, try it
  • for simple questions it terminates MUCH faster than peer frontier models
  • it communicates chain of thought very well

basically this thing is just destroying every other model in our Frontier arena.

items.title:
🚨TL;DR: Benchmarking for AI Scientists just got better!🚨
Everyone is excited about AI Scientists, bu...
items.content:
🚨TL;DR: Benchmarking for AI Scientists just got better!🚨
Everyone is excited about AI Scientists, but we don't have a large scale benchmark that evaluates automated (or augmented) AI research systems on the home turf of the machine learning community: Machine Learning benchmarks. 
Meet AIRS-Bench, our attempt at filling this gap. We hope AIRS-Bench will help the community to improve the signal-to-noise ratio in the era of research agents and is an important step towards turning ML benchmarks into standardised tasks for AI research agents. This has implications beyond AI scientists and will also help address the replication crisis in ML. 

The team has invested countless hours (human and GPU) selecting/constructing the tasks, running baseline agents, analysing the outcomes, and hardening the benchmark. 
We are excited for the community to both expand on our initial task set and benchmark new agentic systems!
items.author: @j_foerst
items.summary: Researchers introduce AIRS-Bench, a large-scale benchmark for evaluating AI research agents on ML tasks. Aims to improve signal-to-noise ratio for research agents and help address the ML replication crisis by standardizing tasks.
items.reasoning: Novel benchmark for AI research agents — an increasingly important area. Addresses real gap in evaluation. Moderate engagement. Relevant to the growing AI-for-science movement.
items.summary_html: Researchers introduce AIRS-Bench, a large-scale benchmark for evaluating AI research agents on ML tasks. Aims to improve signal-to-noise ratio for research agents and help address the ML replication crisis by standardizing tasks.
items.content_html:
🚨TL;DR: Benchmarking for AI Scientists just got better!🚨

Everyone is excited about AI Scientists, but we don't have a large scale benchmark that evaluates automated (or augmented) AI research systems on the home turf of the machine learning community: Machine Learning benchmarks.

Meet AIRS-Bench, our attempt at filling this gap. We hope AIRS-Bench will help the community to improve the signal-to-noise ratio in the era of research agents and is an important step towards turning ML benchmarks into standardised tasks for AI research agents. This has implications beyond AI scientists and will also help address the replication crisis in ML.

The team has invested countless hours (human and GPU) selecting/constructing the tasks, running baseline agents, analysing the outcomes, and hardening the benchmark.

We are excited for the community to both expand on our initial task set and benchmark new agentic systems!

items.title: You know what will be the next big deal in coding AI? (I'm sure they are already working on a model ...
items.content:
You know what will be the next big deal in coding AI? (I'm sure they are already working on a model for this because it's conceptually very simple to implement and has only cash as a constraint.)

The model will be trained to convert the binary of software into the corresponding source code.

So, you upload Adobe Premiere, for example, and say something like, "I need an app like that, but it must be an original app, not a full replica," and it generates source code for an app that has the same functionality as Adobe Premiere but is legally clean (just like the text they generate to answer your question based on a stolen book's content is legally "clean" because it's not exactly the same text they stole).
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov predicts the next big AI coding model will be trained to decompile/reverse-engineer binary software into source code, enabling functional clones of commercial software like Adobe Premiere.
items.reasoning: Provocative and original prediction from ML author Burkov with strong engagement (17K views, 153 likes). Raises significant legal/IP questions. Technically debatable but thought-provoking.
items.summary_html: Burkov predicts the next big AI coding model will be trained to decompile/reverse-engineer binary software into source code, enabling functional clones of commercial software like Adobe Premiere.

items.title: The whole field of structured (aka "tabular") data is still very poorly researched. One of the holy ...
items.content: The whole field of structured (aka "tabular") data is still very poorly researched. One of the holy grails for the ML for tabular data is to have an automated system that can *combine* several tables, extract relevant information, and then create the best ML model for it. We are far, far from that reality.
items.author: @tunguz
items.summary: Tunguz argues that ML for tabular/structured data is still poorly researched. Identifies the holy grail as automated systems that can combine multiple tables, extract relevant info, and build optimal ML models. Says we're far from this.
items.reasoning: Substantive ML insight from a well-followed data science figure. High engagement (184 likes, 27.7K views). Identifies a genuine gap in ML research that contrasts with LLM hype. Tabular data remains the bread and butter of enterprise ML.
items.summary_html: Tunguz argues that ML for tabular/structured data is still poorly researched. Identifies the holy grail as automated systems that can combine multiple tables, extract relevant info, and build optimal ML models. Says we're far from this.
items.content_html: The whole field of structured (aka "tabular") data is still very poorly researched. One of the holy grails for the ML for tabular data is to have an automated system that can *combine* several tables, extract relevant information, and then create the best ML model for it. We are far, far from that reality.

If that gets cracked, writing will be bitter lessoned.

Identifies a specific bottleneck (machine verifiability of writing quality) that explains why AI writing hasn't improved as fast as coding. The 'bitter lesson' reference and RL-for-writing framing is original and thought-provoking. Good engagement (29 likes).

items.title: Such a weird question in the first place -- it is basically impossible for any word not to carry sem...
items.content:
Such a weird question in the first place -- it is basically impossible for any word not to carry semantic value. Let's say you introduce "uh" purely as a filler when speaking, and absolutely no other purpose, then "uh" has automatically acquired semantic value as a signifier of orality, and will be used in written contexts to evoke orality.

The only way a word could *not* carry semantic value is if it is inserted 100% at random. If it is non random then it has meaning. It has at least the meaning of evoking the non-random context in which it gets used.
items.author: @fchollet
items.summary: Chollet argues that it's nearly impossible for any word not to carry semantic value — even 'filler' words like 'uh' acquire meaning from their non-random usage context. The only way a word lacks meaning is if inserted 100% at random.
items.reasoning: Thoughtful linguistics observation from Chollet. High engagement (468 likes) but tangential to core AI topics. Relevant to how language models process meaning.
items.summary_html: Chollet argues that it's nearly impossible for any word not to carry semantic value — even 'filler' words like 'uh' acquire meaning from their non-random usage context. The only way a word lacks meaning is if inserted 100% at random.
items.content_html:
Such a weird question in the first place -- it is basically impossible for any word not to carry semantic value. Let's say you introduce "uh" purely as a filler when speaking, and absolutely no other purpose, then "uh" has automatically acquired semantic value as a signifier of orality, and will be used in written contexts to evoke orality.

The only way a word could *not* carry semantic value is if it is inserted 100% at random. If it is non random then it has meaning. It has at least the meaning of evoking the non-random context in which it gets used.

items.title: @elonmusk I did a little looking into vacuum laser comms when I wrote this, and my takeaway was that...
items.content: @elonmusk I did a little looking into vacuum laser comms when I wrote this, and my takeaway was that while you could get much longer distances (moon-bounce!), the data rates were more power limited because of diffraction, so not as tantalizingly-practical as just a pair of off the shelf optical serdes and a bucket of fiber.
items.author: @ID_AA_Carmack
items.summary: John Carmack replies to Elon Musk about vacuum laser communications, noting that while longer distances are possible (moon-bounce), data rates are power-limited due to diffraction, making off-the-shelf optical serdes with fiber more practical.
items.reasoning: Technical insight from Carmack to Musk on laser communications vs fiber optics. Strong engagement (119 likes, 8K views). Original technical analysis from a highly credible source.
items.summary_html: John Carmack replies to Elon Musk about vacuum laser communications, noting that while longer distances are possible (moon-bounce), data rates are power-limited due to diffraction, making off-the-shelf optical serdes with fiber more practical.
items.content_html: @elonmusk I did a little looking into vacuum laser comms when I wrote this, and my takeaway was that while you could get much longer distances (moon-bounce!), the data rates were more power limited because of diffraction, so not as tantalizingly-practical as just a pair of off the shelf optical serdes and a bucket of fiber.

items.title: The variety of responses and copes I've gotten from various people in tech have just reaffirmed seve...
items.content:
The variety of responses and copes I've gotten from various people in tech have just reaffirmed several things I've known for a while.

1. People in tech are vastly ignorant about *SCIENTIFIC PROCESS AND SCIENTIFIC THINKING*.

2. In particular, they don't know there are whole fields of research that exist to *SCIENTIFICALLY* study  personnel and job selection process.

3. The basic findings in those fields have been very well established and reproduced for generations, and are applicable in virtually ALL work environments.

4. Amongst those findings are that JOB SAMPLE APPRAISAL is THE best single predictor of the future job performance. 

5. Close second to the above is the *RAW* cognitive ability test (IQ, standardized test, etc.)

6. LeetCode style interviews are neither of the above two tests.
items.author: @tunguz
items.summary: Tunguz makes a detailed argument about tech hiring, citing scientific research on personnel selection: job sample appraisal is the best predictor of performance, followed by cognitive ability tests, and LeetCode-style interviews are neither.
items.reasoning: High engagement (26K views, 238 likes). Relevant to tech hiring practices and touches on AI-era workforce issues. Original, substantive argument backed by research references.
items.summary_html: Tunguz makes a detailed argument about tech hiring, citing scientific research on personnel selection: job sample appraisal is the best predictor of performance, followed by cognitive ability tests, and LeetCode-style interviews are neither.
items.content_html:
The variety of responses and copes I've gotten from various people in tech have just reaffirmed several things I've known for a while.

1. People in tech are vastly ignorant about *SCIENTIFIC PROCESS AND SCIENTIFIC THINKING*.

2. In particular, they don't know there are whole fields of research that exist to *SCIENTIFICALLY* study personnel and job selection process.

3. The basic findings in those fields have been very well established and reproduced for generations, and are applicable in virtually ALL work environments.

4. Amongst those findings are that JOB SAMPLE APPRAISAL is THE best single predictor of the future job performance.

5. Close second to the above is the *RAW* cognitive ability test (IQ, standardized test, etc.)

6. LeetCode style interviews are neither of the above two tests.

items.title: @baekpro I have been telling the auto industry for years that they're screwed, but they don't listen...
items.content:
@baekpro I have been telling the auto industry for years that they're screwed, but they don't listen and they don't change. There's only one option for the rest of the industry: hook up to NVIDIA and share your data with them so they can build a data flywheel to compete with Tesla.

Until you all do that, Tesla is going to be way out in front. I don't believe you're ever going to catch Tesla. The big automakers are too slow, too political, and too conservative. They have screwed up over and over for the last 15 years, so I don't believe that you're going to be able to catch Elon.

items.title: We believe Perch 2.0 is so successful at transferring bird data to underwater sounds because of its ...
items.content:
We believe Perch 2.0 is so successful at transferring bird data to underwater sounds because of its ability to:

Generalize: it can expertly categorize sounds not included in its training.
Classify similar sounds: it’s forced to learn detailed acoustic features.
Recognise diversity: identify a variety of species that have evolved vocalizations, yet still share structural characteristics.
items.author: @GoogleDeepMind
items.summary: Google DeepMind explains why Perch 2.0 successfully transfers bird sound data to underwater sounds — through generalization, fine-grained classification, and recognition of structural diversity across species.
items.reasoning: Technical detail about transfer learning in bioacoustics. Interesting AI-for-science application but niche audience.
items.summary_html: Google DeepMind explains why Perch 2.0 successfully transfers bird sound data to underwater sounds — through generalization, fine-grained classification, and recognition of structural diversity across species.
items.content_html:
We believe Perch 2.0 is so successful at transferring bird data to underwater sounds because of its ability to:

Generalize: it can expertly categorize sounds not included in its training.

Classify similar sounds: it’s forced to learn detailed acoustic features.

Recognise diversity: identify a variety of species that have evolved vocalizations, yet still share structural characteristics.

items.title: @sqs I predict the software industry is actually going to be many times bigger in a few years. Just ...
items.content:
@sqs I predict the software industry is actually going to be many times bigger in a few years. Just watch: every company is going to automate. That means they need a lot more software built, because a lot of businesses in the world are very different from each other.

Then we're going to get to:
1. Robots
2. Augmented reality glasses
3. Brain-computer interfaces

All of these will need a lot more software. Now, somebody is going to write that. Maybe they're only talking a few words into an AI, but somebody has to know the right words to say.

items.title: AGI remains a research horizon, but Ant Group’s recent exploration of embodied AI offers a concrete ...
items.content:
AGI remains a research horizon, but Ant Group’s recent exploration of embodied AI offers a concrete view on how current architectures move beyond purely digital systems by integrating models, applications, and hardware within a single research trajectory.

#AntGroupPartner #AGI 

Recent work from Robbyant highlights embodied AI as a space to explore grounding, perception, and long-horizon consistency through simulation and world models.

Placed within Ant Group’s broader full-stack approach, spanning foundational models from the Ant Ling series, multimodal applications such as the LingGuang assistant, and embodied systems, this work connects models, applications, and physical-world interaction within a single architectural direction.

The open and collaborative path, supported through InclusionAI and open-sourced models, frames this effort as ecosystem-driven research rather than a closed, product-centric narrative.
items.author: @antgrasso
items.summary: Antonio Grasso discusses Ant Group's embodied AI research through Robbyant, covering grounding, perception, and long-horizon consistency through simulation and world models, within Ant Group's full-stack approach spanning foundational models (Ant Ling series), multimodal apps, and open-source efforts through InclusionAI.
items.reasoning: Substantive analysis of Ant Group's embodied AI strategy connecting models, applications, and physical-world interaction. Decent engagement (66 likes). Partner content but provides meaningful technical context.
items.summary_html: Antonio Grasso discusses Ant Group's embodied AI research through Robbyant, covering grounding, perception, and long-horizon consistency through simulation and world models, within Ant Group's full-stack approach spanning foundational models (Ant Ling series), multimodal apps, and open-source efforts through InclusionAI.
items.content_html:
AGI remains a research horizon, but Ant Group’s recent exploration of embodied AI offers a concrete view on how current architectures move beyond purely digital systems by integrating models, applications, and hardware within a single research trajectory.

#AntGroupPartner #AGI

Recent work from Robbyant highlights embodied AI as a space to explore grounding, perception, and long-horizon consistency through simulation and world models.

Placed within Ant Group’s broader full-stack approach, spanning foundational models from the Ant Ling series, multimodal applications such as the LingGuang assistant, and embodied systems, this work connects models, applications, and physical-world interaction within a single architectural direction.

The open and collaborative path, supported through InclusionAI and open-sourced models, frames this effort as ecosystem-driven research rather than a closed, product-centric narrative.

items.title: There will come a morning when a man sits alone in a room and builds another room, and inside that r...
items.content: There will come a morning when a man sits alone in a room and builds another room, and inside that room another man sits alone and builds a world. It will not matter whether the world is real. It will behave as if it is, and that will be enough. Every collision, every cell dividing in the dark, every weather pattern spiraling over a simulated coast. All of it faithful to laws no one had to write because the machine watched and learned them on its own. The question will stop being can we model reality and become something harder: what do we owe a reality we invented? Because once you can generate anything, a city, a body, a childhood... the world will split, not between those who have and those who don't, but between those who dream and those who still insist on touching the thing itself.
items.author: @c_valenzuelab
items.summary: Cristóbal Valenzuela posts a philosophical meditation on AI-generated realities, questioning what we owe to simulated worlds and predicting a split between those who dream digitally and those who insist on physical reality.
items.reasoning: Thoughtful philosophical post from RunwayML CEO about simulation and AI-generated worlds. Moderate engagement. More literary than technical.
items.summary_html: Cristóbal Valenzuela posts a philosophical meditation on AI-generated realities, questioning what we owe to simulated worlds and predicting a split between those who dream digitally and those who insist on physical reality.
items.content_html: There will come a morning when a man sits alone in a room and builds another room, and inside that room another man sits alone and builds a world. It will not matter whether the world is real. It will behave as if it is, and that will be enough. Every collision, every cell dividing in the dark, every weather pattern spiraling over a simulated coast. All of it faithful to laws no one had to write because the machine watched and learned them on its own. The question will stop being can we model reality and become something harder: what do we owe a reality we invented? Because once you can generate anything, a city, a body, a childhood... the world will split, not between those who have and those who don't, but between those who dream and those who still insist on touching the thing itself.

@nichochar What really excites me about Ai is that we aren't focusing on "writing code" anymore.

Th...
items.content:
@nichochar What really excites me about Ai is that we aren't focusing on "writing code" anymore.

That's table stakes.

Now, these agents:

• Build the UI
• Send emails and handle notifications
• Set up authentication and user management
• Track analytics and monitor performance

It seems that every day we are automating more and more.

2026 is off to a really great start!

items.title: @LLMJunky The trick if you're building an AI company is to get a better customer base. Now, in my ex...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer argues that AI companies should focus on acquiring 'nerds, early adopters, and builders' as customers because they create better content and make more use of AI tools like OpenAI.
items.reasoning: Interesting strategic insight about AI company customer acquisition and network effects. Shows understanding of community-driven growth.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer argues that AI companies should focus on acquiring 'nerds, early adopters, and builders' as customers because they create better content and make more use of AI tools like OpenAI.
items.content_html:
@LLMJunky The trick if you're building an AI company is to get a better customer base. Now, in my experience, the nerds are way better at content than the jocks. It's a little rude to say that in polite company, but it's true.

Therefore, if you're an AI company at the beginning of your life, you can greatly affect years from now by getting a better customer base early on: nerds, early adopters, and people who build. Those are the people who are going to make a lot more use of OpenAI than any other demographic in society.

Thinking about it more, I have come to agree with you. This was the best ad.

items.title: Liar (or idiot, hard to say from the tweet and AI-generated profile picture). On Llambada, for examp...
items.content:
Liar (or idiot, hard to say from the tweet and AI-generated profile picture). On Llambada, for example, the app builders are watching funny animal videos while their SaaS is being baked for them. They aren't allowed *by design* to touch or even see the code.

LLMs are already familiar with SaaS fundamentals, and platform providers are familiar with the available cloud resources.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov promotes Llambada platform, arguing that no-code SaaS builders don't need to see or touch code, and that LLMs already know SaaS fundamentals.
items.reasoning: Partially promotional for his Llambada platform. Makes interesting points about no-code futures but self-interested.
items.summary_html: Burkov promotes Llambada platform, arguing that no-code SaaS builders don't need to see or touch code, and that LLMs already know SaaS fundamentals.
items.content_html:
Liar (or idiot, hard to say from the tweet and AI-generated profile picture). On Llambada, for example, the app builders are watching funny animal videos while their SaaS is being baked for them. They aren't allowed *by design* to touch or even see the code.

LLMs are already familiar with SaaS fundamentals, and platform providers are familiar with the available cloud resources.

items.title:
AI is now the interface.

Not a menu, not a workflow, not a dashboard.

A conversation.

This shift ...
items.content:
AI is now the interface.

Not a menu, not a workflow, not a dashboard.

A conversation.

This shift is bigger than most teams realize, because it removes the need for users to learn the product.

Here is what that unlocks…

The aha moment I took away from my conversation with Amy Lokey, CXO at @ServiceNow.

#ServiceNowPartner

items.content_html:

Not a menu, not a workflow, not a dashboard.

A conversation.

items.title: Highly rated book from @PacktDataML provides a great Guide to using OpenSearch and its many applicat...
items.content:
Highly rated book from @PacktDataML provides a great Guide to using OpenSearch and its many applications: https://t.co/354NCwCGRp
 ★ ★ ★ ★ ★ 
𝙂𝙤𝙤𝙜𝙡𝙚 𝙨𝙖𝙮𝙨: "OpenSearch is an open-source search and analytics suite that provides scalable full-text search, real-time application monitoring, log analytics, security analytics, and vector database capabilities. Derived from Elasticsearch as a fork, it offers a community-driven, Apache 2.0-licensed solution for data-intensive applications, along with OpenSearch Dashboards for data visualization and exploration. OpenSearch is known for its high availability, performance, and flexibility, allowing users to analyze, visualize, and build data-driven applications across various use cases."
★ ★ ★ ★ ★

𝓑𝓸𝓸𝓴  𝓓𝓮𝓼𝓬𝓻𝓲𝓹𝓽𝓲𝓸𝓷:
From seasoned data professionals managing billions of records to aspiring analysts exploring diverse datasets, this guide is for users at all levels who want to make the most of OpenSearch's capabilities and functionalities. Written by distinguished AWS Solutions Architects Jon Handler, Ph.D., a former search engine developer, Prashant Agrawal, a search specialist, and Soujanya Konka, an expert in large-scale data migrations, this guide brings together deep technical expertise with practical, hands-on knowledge of implementing OpenSearch in real-world scenarios.

Starting with an introduction to OpenSearch, you’ll get to grips with the key features before delving into essential topics such as installing OpenSearch, ingesting data, crafting queries, visualizing results, ensuring security, and optimizing performance. Each concept is accompanied by practical examples and tutorials, allowing you to grasp the material through hands-on experience.

★ ★ ★ ★ ★

𝙂𝙤𝙤𝙜𝙡𝙚 𝙨𝙖𝙮𝙨: "OpenSearch is an open-source search and analytics suite that provides scalable full-text search, real-time application monitoring, log analytics, security analytics, and vector database capabilities. Derived from Elasticsearch as a fork, it offers a community-driven, Apache 2.0-licensed solution for data-intensive applications, along with OpenSearch Dashboards for data visualization and exploration. OpenSearch is known for its high availability, performance, and flexibility, allowing users to analyze, visualize, and build data-driven applications across various use cases."

★ ★ ★ ★ ★

Starting with an introduction to OpenSearch, you’ll get to grips with the key features before delving into essential topics such as installing OpenSearch, ingesting data, crafting queries, visualizing results, ensuring security, and optimizing performance. items.title: @kanaan_cyber There is a backend, but the user doesn't need to think of it. The user just describes ...
items.content:
@kanaan_cyber There is a backend, but the user doesn't need to think of it. The user just describes what the app should do, and the platform decides on the tech stack.

Auth is handled by the platform. Each mini-app runs its own container on GCP as Cloud Run. Data is stored in a managed database in the cloud. So there's really nothing to patch, unless the user wants to ask the AI to patch something for some reason.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov explains Llambada's technical architecture: each mini-app runs in its own GCP Cloud Run container with managed database, auth handled by platform.
items.reasoning: Technical details about Llambada platform architecture. Promotional but informative.
items.summary_html: Burkov explains Llambada's technical architecture: each mini-app runs in its own GCP Cloud Run container with managed database, auth handled by platform.
items.content_html:
@kanaan_cyber There is a backend, but the user doesn't need to think of it. The user just describes what the app should do, and the platform decides on the tech stack.

Auth is handled by the platform. Each mini-app runs its own container on GCP as Cloud Run. Data is stored in a managed database in the cloud. So there's really nothing to patch, unless the user wants to ask the AI to patch something for some reason.

This flexibility does more than simplify workflows.

It collapses user friction.

When a support agent can drop a screenshot, or a field engineer can describe an issue with voice, or a business user can upload a document, AI handles the complexity behind the scenes.

Technology finally meets people where they are.

items.content:
People no longer have to conform to the UI.

The UI conforms to them.

This happens through multi modality.

Users can choose the most natural input:

→ Language
→ Text
→ Images
→ Audio
→ Video
→ Even a simple screenshot

AI handles the translation layer.

A lot has come from X:

Thanks for watching!

items.title: I sometimes see comments like "I read your books and loved them but now I saw your posts and I'm dis...
items.content:
I sometimes see comments like "I read your books and loved them but now I saw your posts and I'm disappointed." This is why I never read or watch anything about artists whose art I love.

Sometimes, I see something in the news headlines that reveals how dumb or evil some of these artists are, and this destroys their art for me.

This is very disappointing, but this happens and there's not much I can do to avoid reading news headlines.

One example is Billie Eilish. She's not my favorite music artist of all times, but some of her songs are truly good. Imagine my disappointment when I read a news headline with this dumb "No illegals on the stolen land" slogan she said during the Grammys.

How can someone be so dumb and hypocrite and make such good music? And if you can, why ruin it by opening your mouth for anything other than singing?

This is what I thought in my head, and the readers of my books should have thought the same when they left those comments under my posts. But at least they could have prevented it by not following me online. I couldn't have prevented this with Billie Eilish.

Sad.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Burkov reflects on the difficulty of separating artists from their public statements, using Billie Eilish as an example.
items.reasoning: Not AI-related personal opinion.
items.summary_html: Burkov reflects on the difficulty of separating artists from their public statements, using Billie Eilish as an example.

items.title: @galluzzo_julian Hmm, I don't have that problem. It's pretty good on my systems (I have a 16 Pro Max...
items.content:
@galluzzo_julian Hmm, I don't have that problem. It's pretty good on my systems (I have a 16 Pro Max). I would clean install your iPhone; that usually fixes this kind of shit.

Apple should make a system that doesn't get into that state for sure, but make sure you get everything backed up. I talked to Grok about clean installing an iPhone; it's worth it every once in a while, and it makes your phone faster anyways.

items.title: @tslaming I have driven many miles in my 2018 Tesla. 155,000. Many of which were at a high rate of s...
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer shares detailed experience of Tesla power failures over 155k miles of ownership.
items.reasoning: Tesla ownership anecdote, tangentially related to tech but not AI-focused.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer shares detailed experience of Tesla power failures over 155k miles of ownership.
items.content_html:
@tslaming I have driven many miles in my 2018 Tesla. 155,000. Many of which were at a high rate of speed. Never had that happen.

But I did run out of power once and everything stayed on. IT tried to save a small amount of power to keep everything on. The tow truck driver said that running out of putter often requires service to reboot all computers. Mine went dead two miles past zero.

Another time lost all power due to small battery going dead. Everything was dead. No lights.

items.title:
One of the most overlooked sources of toxic hormone disruptors are receipts:

> Thermal receipt pape...
items.content:
One of the most overlooked sources of toxic hormone disruptors are receipts:

> Thermal receipt paper is often coated with Bisphenol-A (BPA) or its substitute, Bisphenol-S (BPS), which are endocrine-disrupting chemicals that can absorb into the skin. 

> Studies suggest that even brief 10-second exposure can exceed safe thresholds, potentially harming reproductive, metabolic, and hormonal health

The thermal paper literally leaks BPA into your skin in seconds and then disrupts your hormones heavily:

> BPA (Bisphenol A) is a potent endocrine disruptor that primarily mimics or blocks estrogen (estradiol), but also interferes with androgen, thyroid, and metabolic hormones

> BPA instantly binds to estrogen receptors (ERa, ERb, GPER) and androgen receptors, causing reproductive dysfunction, decreased testosterone, altered FSH/LH levels, and metabolic issues like insulin resistance

This one was wild for me and took me awhile to fact check, because we handle so many receipts in a single day and I couldn't believe it'd be this bad

These days I try ask for a digital receipt or take a quick pic of the receipt without touching it a lot
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio's viral thread about BPA in receipt paper being an overlooked source of hormone disruptors.
items.reasoning: Extremely high engagement (132K views) but entirely about health/chemicals, not AI/ML.
items.summary_html: Levelsio's viral thread about BPA in receipt paper being an overlooked source of hormone disruptors.
items.content_html:
One of the most overlooked sources of toxic hormone disruptors are receipts:

> Thermal receipt paper is often coated with Bisphenol-A (BPA) or its substitute, Bisphenol-S (BPS), which are endocrine-disrupting chemicals that can absorb into the skin.

> Studies suggest that even brief 10-second exposure can exceed safe thresholds, potentially harming reproductive, metabolic, and hormonal health

The thermal paper literally leaks BPA into your skin in seconds and then disrupts your hormones heavily:

> BPA (Bisphenol A) is a potent endocrine disruptor that primarily mimics or blocks estrogen (estradiol), but also interferes with androgen, thyroid, and metabolic hormones

> BPA instantly binds to estrogen receptors (ERa, ERb, GPER) and androgen receptors, causing reproductive dysfunction, decreased testosterone, altered FSH/LH levels, and metabolic issues like insulin resistance

This one was wild for me and took me awhile to fact check, because we handle so many receipts in a single day and I couldn't believe it'd be this bad

These days I try ask for a digital receipt or take a quick pic of the receipt without touching it a lot

items.title:
Things in your house slowly poisoning you, and what to change them to:

Plastic salt/pepper grinders...
items.content:
Things in your house slowly poisoning you, and what to change them to:

Plastic salt/pepper grinders → ceramic
Polyester/nylon clothes → cotton & linen
Plastic cutting boards → wood or ceramic
Plastic food containers → glass
Plastic pyramid tea bags → steel strainer
Receipt paper (BPA) → don't touch them
Plastic cups → glass
Plastic kettle → stainless steel
Polyester bedding → cotton or wool
Polyester towels → cotton
Teflon pans → cast iron or ceramic
Tap water → reverse osmosis filter
items.author: @levelsio
items.summary: Levelsio's viral list of household items slowly poisoning you with suggested replacements (plastic to glass/ceramic/steel etc).
items.reasoning: Very high engagement (135K views) but entirely off-topic health content.
items.summary_html: Levelsio's viral list of household items slowly poisoning you with suggested replacements (plastic to glass/ceramic/steel etc).
items.content_html:
Things in your house slowly poisoning you, and what to change them to:

Plastic salt/pepper grinders → ceramic

Polyester/nylon clothes → cotton & linen

Plastic cutting boards → wood or ceramic

Plastic food containers → glass

Plastic pyramid tea bags → steel strainer

Receipt paper (BPA) → don't touch them

Plastic cups → glass

Plastic kettle → stainless steel

Polyester bedding → cotton or wool

Polyester towels → cotton

Teflon pans → cast iron or ceramic

Tap water → reverse osmosis filter
